title: Before 21 January 2021, will the House of Representatives, pursuant to the 12th Amendment, vote to choose a president of the United States?
preds: Contestation of the election in a manner that would result in this situation has been exhausted.
Moving to 0% (from 1%) after the altercations of the 06/01/21. Many thanks to @cdob63 for the advice.
I am only on 1% because I am no expert on US politics. But it seems unlikely.
The president will be chosen by the electoral college.
Declarations from both sides to honour the vote with only fringe minority senators playing to the crowd with an indication of their intent to object.

Yes, I am watching the chaos.  But the facts still stand. BOTH Senate and House have to agree to toss the ballots.  At least the House has a majority of Democrats, meaning it is a no go.  With the Georgia seats open, there are still 50 Republican seats in the Senate, but it is unlikely they could create a consensus.  To date only a dozen Senators have stated they will support an overturning of electoral college votes.  Mitch McConnell has made it clear he does not support such an action.  In the end, after a food fight, the will of the voters will be upheld in Congress, if not in the White House.
Nothing is truly in dispute here. Any disturbances are circus tricks.

Inching up to 1% on news that Senator Hawley will challenge Biden electors https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/30/hawley-challenge-biden-electors-forcing-vote-452319 We'll know more about how the process on Jan. 6 is likely to play out once the rules governing challenges to electors are set out on Jan. 3
I do not believe Congress, as a whole, wants to open this can of worms.

I'm a Late arrival with no score benefit potential, and by betting, I'm knowingly facing the infinitesimal risk of a catastrophic loss/ Brier Bomb.  I am challenging the the Black Swan...  Come and get me. :-)

I see some misunderstanding here in the process.  The original question was placed in case both Presidential Candidates tied. Congress would then vote for the President to break the tie.   There was not a tie.  In order for this question to resolve as yes at this point, one of two things has to happen.   Either the Supreme Court has to throw out the votes of several states, or Congress must agree to throw out the votes of several states. This would give neither candidate a majority of the vote.   The supreme court refused to accept the case from Texas. It has been refiled, but the earlier refusal makes it highly unlikely. Even if they were to accept the case, the political process is written in the constitution and it is unlikely they would do anything other than state that this must be resolved in Congress.  To refuse to accept votes from a state requires both the House of Representatives AND the Senate to concur.  If both do not agree, the electoral college votes stand and they do not need to vote. So both Senate and House would have to agree to throw out the votes of several states. The House has a majority of Democrats, currently the Senate has a majority of the Republican Party.   My projection of either event happening is zero. Your projection should factor in your perception of these events occurring.
The legal proces has no reason to stall
Given the electoral college voting for President-elect Biden and a democrat control of the House, there will not be a vote by Congress on the President.

"A deadline set Tuesday under federal law essentially locks in President-elect Joe Biden’s victory, even though President Donald Trump is still falsely claiming he won reelection ... Other than Wisconsin, every state appears to have met the safe harbor deadline, which means Congress has to accept the electoral votes that will be cast next week and sent to the Capitol for counting on Jan. 6. Those votes will elect Biden as the country’s next president ... Missing the deadline won’t deprive Wisconsin of its 10 electoral votes. Biden electors still will meet in Madison on Monday to cast their votes and there’s no reason to expect that Congress won’t accept them. In any case, Biden would still have more than the 270 votes he needs even without Wisconsin’s." https://apnews.com/article/safe-harbor-law-locks-congress-joe-biden-119b6e1570f33af0baee1493cbbe012b This rules out a scenario in which the House votes to choose a president since this makes it clear that Biden has attained a majority of electoral votes. As delineated in the 12 Amendment: "the person having the greatest number of votes for President, shall be the President, if such number be a majority of the whole number of electors appointed; and if no person have such majority, then from the persons having the highest numbers not exceeding three on the list of those voted for as President, the House of Representatives shall choose immediately, by ballot, the President." https://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/amendmentxii
Ultimately they will ignore the lies and do their job.
It is very likely that it will get this far
The path to a required for this is a di minimis probability.
It's not impossible, but I'm rounding down.
There is no rational route for this to happen without causing massive civil unrest
(no change) 25th before the 12th? (Only one Senator and one Representative needed to trigger certain grey areas.)
Enough states will soon certify their votes to ensure Biden the win.
My brier score has suffered enough. Or is it my accuracy score? Which is the important one? /s
DT won`t be able to stop it.

Baseline is 54 (1.85%) of presidential elections prior to the 2020 election and since 1804 (inclusive). Only one has relied on the 12th amendment (1824). This one does appear to be formulating as contested in such as manner that it will result in a 12th Amendment situation.

Biden has won a convincing victory, lawsuits notwithstanding. 
The 12th Amendment will not be needed in this case.
So because there is a considerable difference between candidates. There a several lawsuits that have been rejected so far.

Down 2%. So far the crazy scenarios may be just a bad dream.
As of today Nov 5, there are enough states yet to report in that a winner can be determined by Friday Nov 6.
It is unlikely that enough states will fail to certify.  Highly likely that any legal disputes would be settled by SCOTUS in a swift manner.
Chances of a tied electoral college appear to be about 1 percent.
Down 3%. No reason for me to hog the highest Brier score on this question. ;-)

I can't find anywhere where this has happened before, and if there is a tie its likely to end up becoming a court issue based on ballot fraud in this election.
Also, 538 puts it at <1% probability: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/
If I understand the question correctly, this only gets a yes neither candidate gets 270 electoral college votes. Which is highly unlikely. Could definitely be convinced to move it down to zero.

Polling suggests a much more decisive result likely. In the event of an indecisive result (which is itself significantly <50%) much more likely that will be resolved either through courts or through extra-constitutional means.
Almost impossible to get a tie in the electoral college with current population voting trends.
I think 538 give this a 1 or 2% chance of happening. I'm sticking with their evaluation.

In 2012, Nate Silverman gave the odds of an electoral tie at 2%. Vegas has betting odds of Donald Trump winning California at -1600, but it does not have odds of an electoral tie because of how unlikely it is to occur.
Nope.  While a tie in the electoral college is technically possible it is very unlikely.
Only adding a slight chance since there is still so much variability in the Electoral map, and I believe one scenario exists where there could be a tie, thus invoking the 12th amendment.

-- The Economist’s model gives a less than 1% chance of a tie in the electoral college. (https://projects.economist.com/us-2020-forecast/president)  
-- 538’s model suggests that there’s a  ~1% chance of a tie where there is no electoral college majority and the House decides the election. (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/) I don't think the prospect of Trump disputing the election in some way meaningfully increases the probability of a tie in the electoral college.

(Initial forecast:) A long-shot (nightmare-) scenario even for 2020 (+ beyond). But primarily because current polling + political forecasting indicates that Donald Trump likely will not be strongly competitive in 2020's Electoral College. Election prognosticators would need to be almost completely wrong, and/or an unforeseen 'black swan' event (somehow 'favoring' Trump) suddenly impacts the U.S. election.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/ https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/national/ https://projects.economist.com/us-2020-forecast/president https://www.270towin.com/maps/consensus-2020-electoral-map-forecast https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/12/biden-tops-270-politico-election-forecast-428837 https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2020/09/28/how-the-house-could-decide-the-presidential-election-electoral-college-tie-contingent-election/#4808ff51bb6e https://thehill.com/opinion/white-house/521167-why-your-house-vote-could-decide-who-becomes-president

The last time the House of Rep had to get involved in the Presidential vote was in 1824 and it was largely due to two other candidates that pulled significant electoral votes from the two leading candidates.  This race is largely between only two candidates and one seems to have a widening, significant lead over the other in polls as of now.  I think the odds of one party not getting the required 131 electoral votes is slim.
While nothing is impossible, this is a truly Black Swan possibility - so much so I’m surprised it was even asked

Tempting question and I was going to skip it but then I looked at my motto and well here we go.  The electoral tally will be clear.  States have tightened up their rules on the timing of the steps leading up to the electoral college, rules regarding the counting of mail in ballots, and challenge procedures and deadlines.   State courts will have ample means to support whatever judbement they make, if it comes to that.  Any federal appeal will ultimately go to SCOTUS and regardless of whichever party is the appeallant SCOTUS will be consistent with this is a State issue and just be consistent in your application of processes.
The electoral college tally will be clear

Initial forecast. Should only happen in B republics, but rumors of GOP efforts to line up the "troops" in battleground states controlled by them. FUD certainly on Nov 4th. Comparison class is 2000 (ACB part of the team) and BvG. (An interesting question will be whether ACB will recuse herself from the eventual fight.) Very frightening but enlightening article about possible twists and turns: https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2020/11/what-if-trump-refuses-concede/616424/

As I recall, the closest so far was 1876 Tilden-Hayes, which was settled by a lovely corrupt backroom deal and the last-minute appointment of a Republican to fill a slot that was supposed to be for an independent.   (Full disclosure:  I was for Hayes, but only because we were in school together.) Under the current dispensation, the House votes by states and not individuals.  The Rs currently control 26 state delegations, but one of them is Alaska, a one-member Republican delegation that seems vulnerable at the moment.  (D.C. has electoral votes but is not a state and so has no standing to vote on this.)  There are other one-seaters, but they all seem pretty secure.  So if that one seat changes, the House goes to 25-25.  The Constitution has nothing to say about this situation.  There are a couple of other closely divided House delegations that could either eliminate or exacerbate this outcome. And here we are once again lamenting the lack of care taken by the writers of these questions.   The House may vote any number of times before 21 January and be unable to select a Lucky Winner.  So does the question ask whether the House votes, or whether the House actually decides?  My guess is the GJedi meant to ask the latter question, but they didn't. Fun fact:  The Senate, voting by individuals, selects the VP if the electoral collegians can't get it sorted.  So whichever party wins the Senate could name a VP from a party that the ultimately successful Prez does not belong to.  I think Thomas Jefferson was the last President to suffer this indignity, after which the 12th Amendment was supposed to render it impossible.  Nice try, fellas. However, despite the inevitability of an impossible outcome in these deeply weird times, I suspect the regular processes of voting (and challenging votes) will be well and truly concluded in December, probably with a victory for the Doddering Democrat over the Repulsive Republican.
538 has the probability at less than 1 percent. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/

I wish this had been posted a month ago, so maybe the crowd could’ve put it at 20% or so . At this point not at all likely because Biden is already almost at 270. In the early voting, he has insurmountable leads in Wisconsin, Michigan, and Minnesota. Virtually certain to win at least one of: Florida, Arizona, NC. Will win all of them without a dramatic turn around in polls. Trump even down in GA and TX early voting. At this point, shenanigans in Pennsylvania won’t matter
